title: Hyundai Workers in Czech Republic Face Impasse in Wage Negotiations
text:
Wage Negotiations Reach Impasse at Czech Hyundai Plant Negotiations over wages and working conditions at the Hyundai factory in Nošovice , Czech Republic, have stifled, potentially leading to a dispute and potential strike last month.
The unions, who represent employees, have publicly declared that the company’s proposals are detrimental to workers, arguing that the proposed adjustments will significantly diminish both their nominal and actual wages.
Patrik Fupš, leader of the trade union at Hyundai in Nošovice exonerates the company of playing fair. "Everything they propose is in the red," he said, emphasizing the
automotive giant’s proposals would worsen working conditions for employees.
According to the union, Hyundai, for example, has declined to provide an extraordinary bonus tied to a record profit of almost 14 billion crowns, attributing this decision to the need to pay for development and fines levied due to not meeting emission targets.
Further fueling discontent, Hyundai proposes to raise canteen prices, eliminate severance payments in cases of long-term health issues which prevent an employee from working, and lay off 100 employees while simultaneously hiring roughly the same number of workers in October
The workers’ representatives expressed their unwillingness to entertain any further discussions until Hyundai puts forward a contrasting offer, ensuring no worsening of employee conditions. They addressed their proposal was delivered to Hyundai management, who allegedly refused to discuss the union’s proposal any further
"They tried, it didn’t work to reach an agreement," said Fupš, stating negotiations reached an impasse after the second canvassing. "The differences between their proposal and ours are profound.
Now we’ve requested the employer make a genuine counter-proposal,” he added, highlighting the existing collective agreement remains valid until late March.

They claim this ​is needed for⁢ development​ and to cover fines for not meeting emission⁢ targets, but it seems like they’re prioritizing profits over the wellbeing of their​ employees.
**Interviewer:** Are there any⁢ specific ​examples you can share that highlight the difficulties workers are facing?
**Patrik Fupš:** Definitely. They’re‌ even proposing to increase canteen prices, which directly impacts the affordability of ‍meals for our members. It just adds insult to ‌injury.
**Interviewer:** This situation certainly paints a​ worrying picture. What are the next steps‌ for ​the ⁣union?
